1.question: Which countries or states require consent opt-in consent for processing of sensitive personal information?

our_result.content:
### Overview of the Topic

The requirement for opt-in consent for the processing of sensitive personal information is a critical aspect of data protection laws across various jurisdictions. This requirement ensures that individuals have control over their sensitive data, which includes information related to health, racial or ethnic origin, political opinions, religious beliefs, trade union membership, genetic data, biometric data, or sexual orientation. Opt-in consent is a proactive approach where the data subject must take an affirmative action to consent to the processing of their sensitive personal data.

### Key Regulatory Requirements

Opt-in consent for sensitive personal data typically requires that consent be explicit, express, or unambiguous. This means the data subject must clearly and affirmatively agree to the processing of their sensitive personal data, often through a written statement or another clear affirmative action.

### Important Definitions or Concepts

- **Sensitive Personal Information**: This refers to categories of personal data which are considered more sensitive, and therefore require higher protection. Examples include health information, racial or ethnic origin, and political opinions.
- **Opt-in Consent**: This is a form of consent where the data subject must actively provide consent before their sensitive personal data can be processed. It contrasts with opt-out consent, where consent is presumed unless the data subject declines.

### Practical Examples

In practice, opt-in consent can be implemented through mechanisms such as checkboxes on digital forms that are not pre-ticked, explicit consent forms for health services, or detailed consent agreements for membership in political or religious organizations.

### Jurisdiction-Specific Requirements

**Costa Rica:**
- In Costa Rica, the processing of sensitive personal data requires express consent. This aligns with the general principle that express consent is needed for the processing of any personal data, with a heightened requirement for sensitive data. This is based on the regulatory framework which specifies that express consent is necessary for such categories of data [Regulation to the Law of Protection of the Person Against the Treatment of Their Personal Data Article 5].

**Estonia:**
- Estonia requires that the processing of sensitive personal data must be done only with the explicit consent of the data subject. This is explicitly stated in their data protection framework, ensuring that data subjects must clearly and affirmatively agree to the processing of their sensitive personal data [Estonian Personal Data Protection Act Article 9].

**Denmark:**
- Denmark mandates that sensitive personal data can only be processed with explicit consent from the data subject. This requirement is part of the broader data protection regulations that emphasize the protection of sensitive data by requiring a clear affirmative action from the data subject before any processing can occur [Danish Data Protection Act Article 7].

These jurisdictions illustrate the global emphasis on protecting sensitive personal data through stringent consent requirements, ensuring that data subjects are fully aware and agreeable to the processing of their sensitive information.

citations.regulation: Regulation to the Law of Protection of the Person Against the Treatment of Their Personal Data
citations.full_citation: [Regulation to the Law of Protection of the Person Against the Treatment of Their Personal Data Article 5]

gpt_result.question: Which countries or states require consent opt-in consent for processing of sensitive personal information?
gpt_result.full_content:
1. Which countries or states require consent opt-in consent for processing of sensitive personal information?

Summary
Across the documents supplied, opt-in (express / explicit) consent is singled-out as a lawful basis for handling sensitive-category personal data (health, biometrics, beliefs, etc.) in four jurisdictions:

Jurisdiction	Core rule in the text (exact quotation)	Practical effect
Costa Rica	“Quien recopile datos personales deberá, en todos los casos, obtener el consentimiento expreso del titular para el tratamiento de los datos personales” (Art. 5)
Collecting “datos sensibles … sin el consentimiento de su titular” is listed as an infringement (Art. 59 h)	Processing of any personal data—and therefore all sensitive data—requires an affirmative, opt-in consent, save for the narrow statutory exceptions set out in Art. 5.
Gabon	“Las decisiones… no podrán basarse en datos personales sensibles, salvo que el interesado haya dado su consentimiento explícito para uno o varios fines específicos” (Art. 14 ter)	A controller may rely on sensitive data only after obtaining the data subject’s explicit, purpose-specific consent (or another public-interest ground named in the same article).
Denmark (illustrative of all EU/EEA states applying the GDPR)	“La prohibición de tratar datos personales sensibles… no se aplica cuando se cumplen las condiciones… punto a) del artículo 9(2) del RGPD” —i.e., “consentimiento explícito” (s. 7(1))
Private actors may handle criminal-offence data “si el interesado ha dado consentimiento explícito” (s. 8(3))	Article 9(1) GDPR bans processing of special-category data; Article 9(2)(a) lifts the ban only where the person has given explicit consent. Denmark’s Act repeats that rule, so controllers must obtain an opt-in unless another Art. 9(2) exception applies.
Estonia	The Act applies the GDPR in full (§ 2) and repeatedly refers to “datos de las categorías especiales según el artículo 9(1) del RGPD” (§ 10 (2))	Because the GDPR is directly applicable, Estonian controllers need explicit consent (Art. 9(2)(a) GDPR) or another Art. 9 ground before processing sensitive data.

Detailed explanation
Latin-American models (Costa Rica & Gabon)

Both systems adopt consent-first approaches. Costa Rica’s Regulation No. 37554-JP demands express consent for all personal-data processing, with only narrow carve-outs, making opt-in unavoidable for sensitive data. Gabon’s 2020 Ordinance is narrower—focusing on automated decision-making—but still conditions any use of sensitive data on the data-subject’s explicit consent unless an overriding public-interest ground is met.

EU / EEA models (example: Denmark & Estonia)

The GDPR (incorporated verbatim in Denmark’s Act and made directly applicable by Estonia’s Act) forbids processing of “special categories of personal data” (Art. 9 (1)) unless one of the Art. 9 (2) derogations applies.

The first derogation, Art. 9 (2)(a), is the data subject’s “explicit consent to one or more specified purposes.”

National statutes reiterate or cross-reference that rule; hence controllers in every EU/EEA country must secure an opt-in where no other Art. 9 ground fits.

Scope of obligation

In Costa Rica and Gabon, explicit consent is effectively the sole doorway for routine private-sector use of sensitive data.

In EU/EEA jurisdictions, explicit consent is one viable doorway; others (e.g., vital-interest, substantial-public-interest grounds) may remove the consent requirement, but where those do not apply, controllers must fall back on opt-in consent.

Source table
Regulation / Topic	Document name	Page / Art.	Exact text
Costa Rica – Consent rule	Reglamento a la Ley de Protección de la Persona… (No. 37554-JP)	Ch. II, Art. 5	“obtener el consentimiento expreso del titular”
Costa Rica – Infringement	Same	Art. 59 h	“Se recogen… datos sensibles… sin el consentimiento de su titular”
Gabon – Sensitive data	Ordonnance No. 00002/PR/2020	Art. 14 ter	“…no podrán basarse en datos personales sensibles, salvo… consentimiento explícito”
Denmark – Sensitive data gateway	Act No. 502/2018 (Data Protection Act)	§ 7(1)	“…no se aplica… cuando se cumplen… punto a) del Artículo 9(2) RGPD”
Denmark – Criminal-offence data	Same	§ 8(3)	“…pueden tratarse… si el interesado ha dado consentimiento explícito”
Estonia – GDPR reference	Personal Data Protection Act (Riigikogu, 2018)	§ 10(2)	“special categories… Artículo 9(1) RGPD”

Feel free to let me know if you need a deeper comparison or have another jurisdiction in mind.

gpt_result.full_content:
----------------

2. Which countries or states have requirements around obtaining consent from parents or guardians for processing data of minors (under 18 years of age)?

Summary

The documents you supplied show three jurisdictions that expressly require parent/guardian consent before personal data about minors may be processed:

Jurisdiction	Age-trigger	Main context
Denmark	< 13 yrs	Any information-society service offered directly to a child
Estonia	< 13 yrs	Any information-society service offered directly to a child
Georgia (U.S.-state)	< 13 yrs (or ≥ 13 if the student does not give consent)	Use or disclosure of K-12 student data by online “operators”

Below you will find the exact clauses, with full traceability to the document and file you provided.

Detailed evidence
Jurisdiction	Document name	File name	Page / Article / Section	Exact regulatory text
Denmark	Act on supplementary provisions to the GDPR (Data Protection Act), Act No. 502 of 23 May 2018	8 - 2257969a-b379-4eac-8c04-f8eebb276090.pdf	§ 6 (3)	“If the child is under 13, the processing is only lawful if and to the extent that consent is given or approved by the holder of parental responsibility for the child.”
Estonia	Personal Data Protection Act (“Isikuandmete kaitse seadus”), in force 15 Jan 2019	4 - d6e380f3-ea47-4306-a1fa-bbc9bb44a267.pdf	p. 3 / 19, § 8 (2)	“If the child is below the age of 13 years, processing of personal data is permitted only in the case and to the extent for which consent has been given by the legal representative of the child.”
Georgia (USA)	Official Code of Georgia Annotated, Title 20 § 20-2-666 (‘Student Data Privacy, Accessibility, and Transparency Act’)	10 - 1f6c8eb0-241e-41b9-8a00-c8679a0ca28e.pdf	§ 20-2-666 (a)	“An operator shall not knowingly engage in any of the following activities … without explicit written consent from the student’s parent or guardian, or an eligible student.”

How to interpret the requirements
EU Member States (Denmark, Estonia). Article 8 GDPR lets each state set the parental-consent age between 13 and 16. Both Acts you provided pick 13. Processing children’s data below that age requires verified consent or approval from a “holder of parental responsibility”.

Georgia. Section 20-2-666 forbids operators from using, selling, or disclosing student data unless they have a) consent from a parent/guardian or b) consent from an eligible student (the code defines an “eligible student” as 18 + yrs or post-secondary, and separately recognises student self-consent for those over 13). In practice, for K-12 students under 13, the operator must obtain parental consent.

No other parental-consent clauses were located in the remaining PDFs you supplied. If you need confirmation for additional jurisdictions, please provide their source texts.
